Sharks possess a remarkable ability to detect electrical fields in their environment, a sense known as electroreception. <[silence]> This capability is facilitated by specialized sensory organs called the ampullae of Lorenzini. <[silence]> These gel-filled pores are located primarily around the shark's head and are highly sensitive to minute electrical signals. <[silence]> The ampullae of Lorenzini enable sharks to perceive the bioelectric fields generated by other marine organisms, aiding in navigation and prey detection. <[silence]>

The detection of electrical signals plays a significant role in a shark's hunting strategy. <[silence]> Sharks can sense the weak electrical fields produced by the muscle contractions of their prey, even when concealed under sand or in murky waters. <[silence]> This ability allows them to locate hidden or camouflaged prey with impressive accuracy. <[silence]> The sensitivity of the ampullae of Lorenzini is such that sharks can detect voltage gradients as small as a few billionths of a volt per centimeter. <[silence]>

Research has shown that sharks use their electrical sense not only for hunting but also for orientation and navigation. <[silence]> It is believed that they can detect the Earth's magnetic field, which assists in long-distance migration. <[silence]> This sensory adaptation is a testament to the evolutionary success of sharks as apex predators in marine ecosystems. <[silence]> Understanding shark electroreception provides insights into their behavior and ecological roles. <[silence]>

Three related subjects are the role of magnetoreception in animal navigation, the evolution of sensory systems in marine life, and the impact of electromagnetic pollution on aquatic species.
